trans-unit.source: Provides information about systemic errors.
ASP.NET health monitoring allows production and operations staff to manage deployed Web applications.
The <xref:System.Web.Management> namespace contains the health-event types responsible for packaging application health-status data and the provider types responsible for processing this data.
It also contains supporting types that help during the management of health events.
The <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> provides information about errors caused by problems with configuration or application code.
An example is the error issued by ASP.NET when an error is found in a page.

In most cases you will be able to use the ASP.NET health-monitoring types as implemented, and you will control the health-monitoring system by specifying values in the `healthMonitoring` configuration section.
You can also derive from the health-monitoring types to create your own custom events and providers.
For an example of deriving from the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> class, see the example provided in this topic.
Initializes the <xref href="System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent"></xref> class using the supplied parameters.
The <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent.%23ctor%2A> constructor is not intended to be used directly from your code.
It is called by ASP.NET.
You can call the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent.%23ctor%2A> constructor when deriving from the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> class.
The event description.
The object that is the source of the event.
The code associated with the event.
When you implement a custom event, the event code must be greater than <xref href="System.Web.Management.WebEventCodes.WebExtendedBase"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Exception"></xref> associated with the error.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent"></xref> class using the supplied parameters.
The <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent.%23ctor%2A> constructor is not intended to be used directly from your code.
It is called by ASP.NET.
You can call the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent.%23ctor%2A> constructor when deriving from the <xref:System.Web.Management.WebErrorEvent> class.
The event description.
The object that is the source of the event.
The code associated with the event.
When you implement a custom event, the event code must be greater than <xref href="System.Web.Management.WebEventCodes.WebExtendedBase"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Web.Management.WebEventCodes"></xref> value that specifies the detailed identifier for the event.
The <xref href="System.Exception"></xref> associated with the error.
Used internally to increment performance counters.
Gets the application request information.
A <xref href="System.Web.Management.WebRequestInformation"></xref> object that contains information about the current request.
Gets the application-thread information.
A <xref href="System.Web.Management.WebThreadInformation"></xref> object that contains information about the current thread.
